Big numbers are a good idea to encourage searching more than a greedy algorithm.

I really enjoyed this challenge, but, implementing a simple recursive "imbalance descent" in python led to maximum recursion depth reached from test 6 ...
So, with matrix elements being smaller than 10^6 I think in is quite simple. But after that, some optimization is required no ?
While trying to solve it, I was like "My goodness, is there a simple mathematical solution I am missing, like, using a determinant or something?" but I couldn't figure out.
So unless there is a nice optimization trick to think about, or a mathematical shortcut, I think tests after level 5 go to too large numbers. Of course, it could be possible to use a dirty trick like enlarging steps when the imbalance is large, but nothing tells us it has to eventually converge to reasonably small imbalance so, this type of solution wouldn't be good in my opinion, unless there is a good criterion to know whether the steps should be coarse or fine.
This problem of maximum recursion depth is certainly language-dependant and for sure Python isn't the best for that, but unless I miss something, such large numbers of required steps don't add any interest to the challenge, do they?
Basically we can check the initial imbalance, and then recursively try to find which row/col decreases it, and keep going until it stops decreasing... It's a fun one, probably even underrated

Find minimal imbalance you can obtain. Imbalance is max(engines) - min(engines), in example 1 1 0 3 imbalance is 3 - 0 = 3, because 3 is maximum number, and 0 is minimum number, but that is not minimal possible imbalance you can obtain, that is default imbalance, for example you can increase by one every number in first row, second row, first column or second column, example you can increase first row and get 2 2 0 3, like in example or you can increase first column and get 2 1 1 3 ( pretend like this four numbers are in matrix ). Minimal possible solution is 2, in given example 4 2 2 3, 2 = 4 - 2, or in this comment second example 2 1 1 3, 3 - 1 = 2. Solution is really simple, but it is a bit harder how to find that solution, of course maybe there is different solution from mine.
There is nice mathematical formula, or like you said shortcut, to optimize your solution, it is not really easy to figure out it, but it can be proved, so it is not impossible to find out it.
